name: Vitamin E
summary: Vitamin E is a fat-soluble antioxidant that protects cell membranes from oxidative stress. It exists in multiple forms, with alpha-tocopherol being the most biologically active in humans.
description: Vitamin E is a collective term for eight fat-soluble compounds: four tocopherols (alpha, beta, gamma, delta) and four tocotrienols. Alpha-tocopherol is the predominant and most active form in human tissues. Vitamin E functions primarily as an antioxidant, protecting cell membranes, lipids, and low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol from free radical damage. It also has roles in immune function, gene expression, and cell signaling. Supplementation is mainly used to correct deficiency (rare) or investigated for its potential benefits in cardiovascular health, eye health, neurodegenerative disorders, and skin conditions, though evidence for disease prevention is mixed.

metadata.natural_source: Vegetable oils (sunflower, safflower, wheat germ, soybean), nuts, seeds, green leafy vegetables

primary_indications: Vitamin E deficiency (rare; often due to fat malabsorption disorders, e.g. cystic fibrosis, cholestatic liver disease, abetalipoproteinemia)
off_label_uses: Adjunct in nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD)
Age-related macular degeneration (as part of antioxidant formulations)
contraindications: Vitamin K deficiency or anticoagulant therapy (risk of bleeding at high doses)
History of hemorrhagic stroke (high-dose vitamin E linked to increased risk)
monitoring_required: Bleeding risk in patients on anticoagulants

items: Adjunctive use in oxidative stress–related disorders (investigational)

sections.text: Vitamin E functions as a lipid-soluble antioxidant, preventing propagation of free radical chain reactions in membranes and lipoproteins. It stabilizes cell membranes, protects polyunsaturated fatty acids from lipid peroxidation, and may modulate immune function and gene expression.
Correction of deficiency symptoms (e.g., neuropathy, hemolytic anemia) may take weeks to months of supplementation.

common: Generally well tolerated at RDA doses
serious: Increased bleeding risk at high doses
Potential increased mortality in very high-dose trials

other: High-dose supplementation (>400 IU/day) may increase bleeding risk and mortality in some studies.
Use with caution in patients on anticoagulants or with vitamin K deficiency.

items.risk: Potential interference with oxidative stress–based therapy
items.action: Avoid high-dose supplementation unless advised by clinician

items: Clinical response (neurological, hematologic improvement in deficiency)
Bleeding risk if combined with anticoagulants

sections.pregnancy: Safe at recommended daily allowance (15 mg/day); avoid high doses
sections.pediatrics: Safe at age-appropriate doses; essential in preventing hemolysis in premature infants
sections.geriatrics: Safe; high doses may increase bleeding risk

sections.text: Not required; however, sudden discontinuation after high-dose use may reduce antioxidant defenses.

items: Deficiency is rare and usually secondary to malabsorption or genetic disorders.
Evidence for cardiovascular and cancer prevention is inconsistent or negative.
Vitamin E is a key component of the AREDS2 formulation for slowing progression of age-related macular degeneration.
Alpha-tocopherol is the most studied form; gamma-tocopherol and tocotrienols may have distinct biological effects.
